_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Mann Packing Gonzales conducts inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment prior to startup and during operations. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. On-site personnel and certified refrigeration contractors review the equipment as required. 

Mann Packing Gonzales is a "Non-Responding" facility and does not respond to ammonia releases including emergency shutdown, equipment isolation, and pumping down the system. The facility has prepared an emergency action plan and, in addition, will coordinate with local emergency responding agencies, specifically, the local fire department. Emergency action plan activities will be limited to hazard identification; notification of employees, local fire department, and surrounding businesses; evacuation of employees; and assistance to the fire department emergency response team if requested.



2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Mann Packing Gonzales uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in their operations. 

The ammonia system is used for cold storage, chilled water generation for produce processing, and air compressor refrigerated cooler. The refrigeration system at the facility is composed of screw and reciprocating type compressors, evaporative condensers, pressure vessels, ammonia pumps, cold room evaporative cooling coils, plate frame type water chillers, falling film chillers (to be added at a later date), ammonia detection, control systems and diffusion tank. 

The facility remains operational throughout the year. The mechanical room houses one low pressure recirculator package, five ammonia pumps, three reciprocating compressors, and two screw compressors. The equipment yard contains two evaporative condensers, one high pressure receiver, one plate frame heat exchanger, and one diffusion tank. All the evaporators and falling film chillers ar

e located inside the cold rooms. Evaporator valve stations are on the roof of the cold rooms.

All compressors have safety switches that would shut down the compressors upon detection of unsafe operating conditions. The refrigeration control system sends alarms to the refrigeration manager in the case of emergency situations or any high pressure, high temperature, or ammonia detection. All pressure vessels and compressors are protected against high-pressure situations by safety relief valves.

There are ammonia detectors in the cold rooms and mechanical room for alarming. The ammonia detection system sends notifications to the facility guard shack (monitored 24/7) and the refrigeration manager. Facility employees are trained in emergency notification procedures as detailed in the Emergency Action Plan. 

The refrigeration system at the facility was constructed as per applicable codes and industry standards at the time of construction. The total ammonia charge of the refrigeration systems at the facility is approximately 23,050 lb.

The refrigeration system at this facility is single-stage vapor compression cycles.

Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may be suffocating as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and/ or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeated or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain and serious skin burn.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Mann Packing Gonzales maintains a release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases. The program includes regular inspections, monitoring equipment and logging conditions, scheduled maintenance, and operator training. There is a program to analyze releases for ways to prevent a similar future release.

The ammonia refrigeration system has specific safety procedures to prevent a release. Operators and contractors are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They are also trained in emergency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, and contractors are trained in emergency shutdown and system pumpdown procedures. There are emergency shut-off switches outside the mechanical room for shutting down the system. Ammonia detectors are installed in all refrigerated rooms and the mechanical room. The ammonia detection system shuts down the refrigeration system if the ammonia concentration in the engine room reaches 10,000 ppm. Personnel will automatically be notified if any ammonia detector exceeds its set point. Monitoring is done 24 hours per day. Automatic crossover valve relieves high pressure from the high side to the low side at predetermined set pressures. All of the relief valves at the facility are tied into an ammonia diffusion tank to prevent high-pressure releases to ambient.



4. Five-Year Accident History

Mann Packing Gonzales Facility is new, so there has been no releases of anhydrous ammonia in the last 5 years.



5. Emergency Response Program

Mann Packing Gonzales Facility is a "Non-Responding" facility. Facility personnel only respond to situations that are within their capabilities. These may include emergency shutdown, equipment isolation and pumping down the system. No emergency response actions or site clean-up that are beyond the capabilities of the refrigeration personnel will be performed. 

In the event of a release, certain personnel are designated to determine the potential hazard and coordinate response procedures. The Safety Coordinator is responsible for coordinating emergency response and will be contacting emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be affected by the release. The Safety Coordinator will also be responsible for evacuating em

ployees if necessary and for coordinating with community emergency responders if off-site evacuations are required.



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Recommended corrective actions to mitigate the potential for an accidental ammonia release are proposed. These corrective items are a result from recommendations made during the Process Hazard Analysis, a Code Compliance Review, and a Safety Inspection performed by a qualified person. Based on the severity of the hazards identified, implementation deadlines are also recommended.

All refrigeration equipment is new and the installing refrigerating contractor performed pressure tests and pre-startup safety checks before the startup of the system. The refrigeration system is operated in a safe manner by trained personnel. Preventative maintenance is preformed by a licensed refrigeration contractor.
